For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

The McGovern-Dole program provides for the donation of agricultural commodities and the provision of financial and technical assistance to improve the education, food security and health of school-age children, especially girls, in developing countries.

Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

Activities included herein should be linked to relevant GJD/Human Rights elements.

column6: Peace and Reconciliation Processes - Peace and Reconciliation Processes
column7: PEACE AND RECONCILIATION PROCESSES - PEACE AND RECONCILIATION PROCESSES
column8: Support and strengthen the negotiation process and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

column6: World Health Organization Consolidated Grant - Malaria
column7: WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION CONSOLIDATED GRANT - MALARIA
column8: This grant provides support for collaborative activities with USAID and the World Health Organization (WHO) in infectious diseases, maternal and child health, family planning, safe motherhood, reproductive health, environmental health and HIV/AIDS. Specifically, support is provided to WHOs relevant technical and program divisions for technical input and assistance in the development, implementation and/or evaluation of health programs and studies including: 1) Global strategy development; 2) Technical analyses; 3) Demonstration activities and feasibility studies; 4) Capacity building; 5) Policy reform; 6) Project evaluation and assessments; 7) Monitoring and evaluation; 8) Education/information strategies; 9) Maternal and neonatal health; 10) Family Planning and Reproductive Health; 11) Implementing Best Practices in Family Planning; and 11) Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC).

column6: Program Research for Strengthening Services (PROGRESS) - Maternal and Child Health
column7: PROGRAM RESEARCH FOR STRENGTHENING SERVICES (PROGRESS) - MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH
column8: The goal of PROGRESS is to improve access to family planning among underserved populations through research and research utilization. To achieve this goal, PROGRESS developed a workplan consisting of four legacy areas. The legacy areas comprise the key organizing structure for identifying and implementing activities, monitoring performance, and assessing achievement of desired outcomes. The legacy areas: 1. Maximizing human resources by task-shifting and addressing medical barriers to family planning services 2. Expanding service delivery options within and beyond the health sector 3. Expanding the family planning method mix for home, community, and lower-level provider use 4. Increasing in-country capacity for research and research utilization.

column6: Systems for Improved Access to Pharmaceuticals and Services (SIAPS) - HIV/AIDS
column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - HIV/AIDS
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

column6: CGIAR Fund grant with the World Bank. - Agricultural Sector Capacity
column7: CGIAR FUND GRANT WITH THE WORLD BANK. - AGRICULTURAL SECTOR CAPACITY
column8: GFSI: CGIAR research is dedicated to reducing rural poverty, increasing food security, improving human health and nutrition, and ensuring sustainable management of natural resources. It is carried out by 15 Centers, that are members of the CGIAR Consortium, in close collaboration with hundreds of partners, including national and regional research institutes, civil society organizations, academia, development organizations and the private sector..

Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

column6: Fistula Care Project - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
column7: FISTULA CARE PROJECT - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
column8: Fistula Care Project - Family Planning and Reproductive Health - Expand sustainable provision of family planning services in clinical and non-clinical programs including those in the public, private, NGO, and PVO sectors, and at the community level; activities that help improve the quality of the services and care provided, including pre- and in-service training of providers and application of evidence-based service-delivery norms and standards; and availability of a wide range of contraceptive options (temporary, fertility awareness methods, and long-acting and permanent methods) for men and women. Improve responsiveness to client needs, including the FP/RH needs of youth and men, women and girls affected by violence, refugees/IDP, and other underserved populations. Also included are activities that integrate FP and related RH care, including integrated FP/MCH services, especially provision of post-partum family planning, FP information within the ANC setting, and post-abortion care; FP, as appropriate, in the context of HIV/AIDS/STI prevention, treatment, care and support; fistula prevention and repair; prevention and mitigation of gender-based violence in the context of FP/RH programs; and programs that encourage abandonment of female genital cutting and other harmful traditional practices that are associated with negative RH outcomes.

column6: Technical Leadership in Public Financial Management -
column7: TECHNICAL LEADERSHIP IN PUBLIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT -
column8: USAIDs Leadership in Public Financial Management and Macroeconomic Analysis program is designed to support rapid, sustainable and equitable economic growth. The program will enable USAID to better address public financial management, sound macroeconomic planning and policies, and other selected economic governance issues. LPFM will support USAID missions abroad by improving a) host-country policy climates for investment in ways that generate more productive employment: b) host-country ability to recover from conflict, post-conflict, natural disasters, financial and/or fiscal crises: c) countries resilience to economic downturns: and d) host-country institutional capacity to identify, design, advocate and implement better economic policies.

column6: Systems for Improved Access to Pharmaceuticals and Services (SIAPS) - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

Also included are activities that integrate FP and related RH care, including integrated FP/MCH services, especially provision of post-partum family planning, FP information within the ANC setting, and post-abortion care; FP, as appropriate, in the context of HIV/AIDS/STI prevention, treatment, care and support; fistula prevention and repair; prevention and mitigation of gender-based violence in the context of FP/RH programs; and programs that encourage abandonment of female genital cutting and other harmful traditional practices that are associated with negative RH outcomes.

column7: PEACE AND RECONCILIATION PROCESSES - PEACE AND RECONCILIATION PROCESSES
column8: Support and strengthen the negotiation process and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.
OFDA/Disaster Response

column8: Behavior Change and Social Marketing Project (BCSM) - Support the implementation of the Presidents Malaria Initiative (PMI), related malaria control programs, and malaria research activities to reduce malaria-related mortality. Develop effective malaria vaccines, new malaria treatment drugs, and targeted operations research.

column6: Public Sector Executive Function - Public Sector Executive Function
column7: PUBLIC SECTOR EXECUTIVE FUNCTION - PUBLIC SECTOR EXECUTIVE FUNCTION
column8: Assist executive offices, ministries, and independent governmental bodies to operate more efficiently and effectively; and assist executive branch offices and citizens to incorporate democratic structures and principles into state building, their ongoing systems of governance, and public administration services. Assist with policies, procedures, and skill sets (including leadership and strategic management) to guide operations; implementation and enforcement of laws, regulations and policies; linkages between and among branches, levels and functions of government; international relations; financial management systems; civil service reforms; public/private partnerships; and working with citizens as customers of the government.

Establish and/or develop viable political parties and political entities that are effective and accountable, that represent and respond to citizens interests, and that govern responsibly and effectively.

Establish and/or develop a broadly functioning independent media sector, which is a crucial factor in democratic governance. Building this sector is accomplished through such activities as providing infrastructure and equipment to ensure access to information, shaping the media legal and regulatory environment, boosting professional capacity of the media sector, promoting sustainability through encouraging media-related business development and sound financial/management practices, and supporting advocacy and networking among media sector organizations.
Strengthen cross-sectoral synergies between democracy and governance and Africa Bureau programs in key areas

Establish and/or develop a broadly functioning independent media sector, which is a crucial factor in democratic governance. Building this sector is accomplished through such activities as providing infrastructure and equipment to ensure access to information, shaping the media legal and regulatory environment, boosting professional capacity of the media sector, promoting sustainability through encouraging media-related business development and sound financial/management practices, and supporting advocacy and networking among media sector organizations.
Improved Governance

Promote peaceful agreement on democratic reform, rules, and frameworks. Promote peaceful, broad-based participation in determining, defining, and negotiating changes to governing structures. Illustrative examples include promoting inclusive consensus-building processes related to peace agreements, national dialogues, referenda on key issues, and constitutional development or reform. Programs are designed to incorporate and support mechanisms that advance conflict mediation, resolution and negotiation of disputes in the context of these processes.
Administration and Oversight (Governance)

Assist with policies, procedures, and skill sets (including leadership and strategic management) to guide operations; implementation and enforcement of laws, regulations and policies; linkages between and among branches, levels and functions of government; international relations; financial management systems; civil service reforms; public/private partnerships; and working with citizens as customers of the government.

column8: PL 480 Title II Multi Year Assistance Program (MYAP) - Provide goods, personnel, services and assistance to meet basic human needs in order to foster transition from relief according to principles of universality, impartiality and human dignity. This element should be done, when possible, as part of an integrated, coordinated and/or multi-sectoral approach.

column6: Fistula Care Project - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
column7: FISTULA CARE PROJECT - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
column8: Fistula Care Project - Family Planning and Reproductive Health - Expand sustainable provision of family planning services in clinical and non-clinical programs including those in the public, private, NGO, and PVO sectors, and at the community level; activities that help improve the quality of the services and care provided, including pre- and in-service training of providers and application of evidence-based service-delivery norms and standards; and availability of a wide range of contraceptive options (temporary, fertility awareness methods, and long-acting and permanent methods) for men and women. Improve responsiveness to client needs, including the FP/RH needs of youth and men, women and girls affected by violence, refugees/IDP, and other underserved populations. Also included are activities that integrate FP and related RH care, including integrated FP/MCH services, especially provision of post-partum family planning, FP information within the ANC setting, and post-abortion care; FP, as appropriate, in the context of HIV/AIDS/STI prevention, treatment, care and support; fistula prevention and repair; prevention and mitigation of gender-based violence in the context of FP/RH programs; and programs that encourage abandonment of female genital cutting and other harmful traditional practices that are associated with negative RH outcomes.

column6: Program Design and Learning - Program Design and Learning - Program Design and Learning
column7: PROGRAM DESIGN AND LEARNING - PROGRAM DESIGN AND LEARNING - PROGRAM DESIGN AND LEARNING
column8: GFSI: Program Design and Learning - Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded operating unit wide programs, not for a specific functional objective. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, public outreach, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Funding for similar activities that are directed to specific functional objectives should be entered in the PD&L sub-element of the appropriate program area(s) within that objective.

Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.

column6: Systems for Improved Access to Pharmaceuticals and Services (SIAPS) - Maternal and Child Health
column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

CapacityPlus - Increase the availability and use of proven life-saving interventions that address the major killers of mothers and children and improve their health and nutrition status, including effective maternity care and management of obstetric complications; prevention services including newborn care, routine immunization, polio eradication, safe water and hygiene, and micronutrients; improved maternal, infant and young child feeding; and treatment of life-threatening childhood illnesses.

column8: Fistula Care Project - Maternal and Child Health - Support registration of pregnancies, infection prevention, nutrition, education about need for a skilled birth attendant and recognition of complications, identification and discouragement of harmful practices such as inadequate provision of food during pregnancy, development of individualized birth plans, constructive engagement of partners and families in support of pregnant women, community based-financing of deliveries, and organization for transport. Support facility-based and outreach services, improving the quality and equitable coverage of antenatal, delivery and postpartum care services, including periodic evaluation of the progress of pregnancy, labor support, use of the partogram, clean delivery, and active management of the third stage of labor.

column8: The Health Policy Project (HPP) works to strengthen developing country national and subnational policy, advocacy, governance, and finance for strategic, equitable, and sustainable health programming. HPP helps countries bring about real change in the health of people and communities. We work with in-country partners to sustain commitment to and ownership of policy responses that support improvements in family planning and reproductive health (FP/RH), HIV, and maternal health.

column8: WASHPlus is a Cooperative Agreement managed by FHI 360 with CARE and Winrock International as core partners, and teamed with a highly talented group of university, private and public sector resource partners in areas such as creative financing, innovation, and public-private partnerships in addition to WASH service delivery. The project is designed to support the further development, introduction and delivery of high-impact interventions in water supply, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) and indoor air quality (IAQ).

column6: Nutrition - Pop-based Nutrition Service Deliv (incl micronutrient suppl) - Nutrition
column7: NUTRITION - POP-BASED NUTRITION SERVICE DELIV (INCL MICRONUTRIENT SUPPL) - NUTRITION
column8: GFSI: Nutrition - Support delivery of nutrition services through sustainable platforms. This sub-element includes but is not limited to micronutrient supplementation programs, community management of acute malnutrition, production of fortified foods, and strengthening nutrition service delivery systems as part of primary health care systems. This sub-element does not include zinc as treatment for diarrhea (included in 3.1.6.7).

column6: Technical Leadership in Public Financial Management - Higher Education
column7: TECHNICAL LEADERSHIP IN PUBLIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT - HIGHER EDUCATION
column8: USAIDs Leadership in Public Financial Management and Macroeconomic Analysis program is designed to support rapid, sustainable and equitable economic growth. The program will enable USAID to better address public financial management, sound macroeconomic planning and policies, and other selected economic governance issues. LPFM will support USAID missions abroad by improving a) host-country policy climates for investment in ways that generate more productive employment: b) host-country ability to recover from conflict, post-conflict, natural disasters, financial and/or fiscal crises: c) countries resilience to economic downturns: and d) host-country institutional capacity to identify, design, advocate and implement better economic policies.

column6: Legislative Function and Processes - Legislative Function and Processes
column7: LEGISLATIVE FUNCTION AND PROCESSES - LEGISLATIVE FUNCTION AND PROCESSES
column8: Improve the way the legislature and legislative processes and procedures work to uphold democratic practices. Focus on the quality and effectiveness of legislation, including the constitution, codes, laws, and regulations applying to various development sectors. Increase the legislatures capacity to be responsive to the people it serves, enhance public participation, engage in policy-making, hold itself and the executive accountable, and oversee the implementation of government programs, budgets, and laws.

column6: Technical Leadership in Public Financial Management - Water Supply and Sanitation
column7: TECHNICAL LEADERSHIP IN PUBLIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT - WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION
column8: USAIDs Leadership in Public Financial Management and Macroeconomic Analysis program is designed to support rapid, sustainable and equitable economic growth. The program will enable USAID to better address public financial management, sound macroeconomic planning and policies, and other selected economic governance issues. LPFM will support USAID missions abroad by improving a) host-country policy climates for investment in ways that generate more productive employment: b) host-country ability to recover from conflict, post-conflict, natural disasters, financial and/or fiscal crises: c) countries resilience to economic downturns: and d) host-country institutional capacity to identify, design, advocate and implement better economic policies.

column6: Private Sector Productivity - Private Sector Capacity
column7: PRIVATE SECTOR PRODUCTIVITY - PRIVATE SECTOR CAPACITY
column8: Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

column6: Indoor Residual Spraying 2 Task Order #1 - Malaria
column7: INDOOR RESIDUAL SPRAYING 2 TASK ORDER #1 - MALARIA
column8: To support planning and implementation of indoor residual spraying (IRS) programs to prevent malaria. This task order will enhance USAIDs ability to implement IRS programs on the ground through cost-effective commodities procurement for IRS, IRS logistics systems, access to technical expertise, and implementation of IRS in countries affected by malaria. The IRS 2 IQC places added emphasis on building the capacity of Ministries of Health and local institutions to plan, conduct, supervise and monitor IRS programs.

Support the implementation of the Presidents Malaria Initiative (PMI), related malaria control programs, and malaria research activities to reduce malaria-related mortality. Develop effective malaria vaccines, new malaria treatment drugs, and targeted operations research.

column6: Systems for Improved Access to Pharmaceuticals and Services (SIAPS) - Malaria
column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - MALARIA
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

column6: Business Enabling Environment - Business Enabling Environment
column7: BUSINESS ENABLING ENVIRONMENT - BUSINESS ENABLING ENVIRONMENT
column8: Improve policies, laws, regulations, and administrative practices affecting the private sector. Includes reducing barriers to competition and unwarranted distortions to market prices; reducing policy and regulatory barriers to establishing, operating, and closing businesses; strengthening the legal framework surrounding property rights that is fair to both men and women, contract enforcement, and dispute resolution, along with the administration of those laws; reducing incentives for corruption and promoting transparent business practices; strengthening the legal framework surrounding intellectual property rights; and improving laws and regulations affecting the creation, dissemination, and use of technology. It also includes improving policies and regulations affecting technology choices and production behaviors with environmental impacts; and improving policies, laws, and regulations affecting hiring and firing of workers, wages, working conditions, and collective bargaining. Includes support for specific improvements as well as efforts to strengthen the institutions that contribute to designing and implementing further improvements.

Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

National Technical Assistance Plus (ATN+) - Malaria - Establish and/or strengthen host country institutions management information systems (MIS) and their development and use of tools and models to collect, analyze and disseminate a variety of information related to the program element. These may include, but are not limited to MIS for government ministries or other host country institutions, needs assessments, baseline studies, censuses and surveys, targeted evaluations, special studies, routine surveillance, data quality assessments, and operational research. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned and testing demonstration and/or pilot models. Related training, supplies, equipment, and non-USG personnel are included. This does not include anything captured under 1.3.6.

column6: Systems for Improved Access to Pharmaceuticals and Services (SIAPS) - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

The Health Policy Project (HPP) works to strengthen developing country national and subnational policy, advocacy, governance, and finance for strategic, equitable, and sustainable health programming. HPP helps countries bring about real change in the health of people and communities. We work with in-country partners to sustain commitment to and ownership of policy responses that support improvements in family planning and reproductive health (FP/RH), HIV, and maternal health.

column6: RESETTLEMENT SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SOCIAL SERVICES ACTIVITY
column7: RESETTLEMENT SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SOCIAL SERVICES ACTIVITY
column8: Resettlement, Social Infrastructure, Social Services (the Community Activity ): The Community Activity will provide funds to implement the RAP, build social infrastructure and support social services, primarily health staff and teachers, to ensure appropriate utilization of the social infrastructure. This Project Activity will compensate families residing in the perimeter or with rights to land therein consistent with World Bank Operational Policy 4.12 on Involuntary Resettlement by offering land in the irrigation perimeter or, if the land option is not chosen, other compensation alternatives. This Project Activity will provide social infrastructure, to serve these project-affected persons plus incoming settlers and other migrant families and also support social services (primarily education and health staff) during the last three years of the Compact Term.

column6: Peace and Reconciliation Processes - Peace and Reconciliation Processes
column7: PEACE AND RECONCILIATION PROCESSES - PEACE AND RECONCILIATION PROCESSES
column8: Support and strengthen the negotiation process and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

column6: Systems for Improved Access to Pharmaceuticals and Services (SIAPS) - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

column6: Graduation with Resilience to Achieve Sustainable Development (GRAD) - Private Sector Capacity
column7: GRADUATION WITH RESILIENCE TO ACHIEVE SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (GRAD) - PRIVATE SECTOR CAPACITY
column8: Graduation with Resilience to Achieve Sustainable Development (GRAD) builds on lessons learned from several predecessor USAID projects and activities, including PSNP Plus. An emphasis will be placed on market linkages, access to microfinance, and diversification of household income sources. Additionally, GRAD will also focus on building the resilience of communities through supporting climate change adaptation activities, which will address the high amount of vulnerability in chronically food insecure areas.

column6: Technical Leadership in Public Financial Management - Local Government and Decentralization
column7: TECHNICAL LEADERSHIP IN PUBLIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT - LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND DECENTRALIZATION
column8: USAIDs Leadership in Public Financial Management and Macroeconomic Analysis program is designed to support rapid, sustainable and equitable economic growth. The program will enable USAID to better address public financial management, sound macroeconomic planning and policies, and other selected economic governance issues. LPFM will support USAID missions abroad by improving a) host-country policy climates for investment in ways that generate more productive employment: b) host-country ability to recover from conflict, post-conflict, natural disasters, financial and/or fiscal crises: c) countries resilience to economic downturns: and d) host-country institutional capacity to identify, design, advocate and implement better economic policies.

column6: World Health Organization Consolidated Grant - Malaria
column7: WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION CONSOLIDATED GRANT - MALARIA
column8: This grant provides support for collaborative activities with USAID and the World Health Organization (WHO) in infectious diseases, maternal and child health, family planning, safe motherhood, reproductive health, environmental health and HIV/AIDS. Specifically, support is provided to WHOs relevant technical and program divisions for technical input and assistance in the development, implementation and/or evaluation of health programs and studies including: 1) Global strategy development; 2) Technical analyses; 3) Demonstration activities and feasibility studies; 4) Capacity building; 5) Policy reform; 6) Project evaluation and assessments; 7) Monitoring and evaluation; 8) Education/information strategies; 9) Maternal and neonatal health; 10) Family Planning and Reproductive Health; 11) Implementing Best Practices in Family Planning; and 11) Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC).

Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

column6: Health Finance and Governance (HFG) Project - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
column7: HEALTH FINANCE AND GOVERNANCE (HFG) PROJECT - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
column8: USAIDs Global Health Bureau launched the Health Finance and Governance (HFG) Project to support countries in their quest for stronger health systems that deliver the life-saving services their citizens need, when and where they can access them, and at affordable prices. HFG is a five-year (20122017), $209 million global project designed to improve health finance and health governance systems in partner countries, leading to expanded access to health care and improved health outcomes. HFG also works with country partners to improve the management of health systems and generate much-needed evidence on the most effective, efficient ways to improve health systems.
BAFDA Artisan Fisheries Project

column6: Health Policy Project (HPP) - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
column7: HEALTH POLICY PROJECT (HPP) - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
column8: The Health Policy Project (HPP) works to strengthen developing country national and subnational policy, advocacy, governance, and finance for strategic, equitable, and sustainable health programming. HPP helps countries bring about real change in the health of people and communities. We work with in-country partners to sustain commitment to and ownership of policy responses that support improvements in family planning and reproductive health (FP/RH), HIV, and maternal health.

column6: Program Research for Strengthening Services (PROGRESS) - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
column7: PROGRAM RESEARCH FOR STRENGTHENING SERVICES (PROGRESS) - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
column8: The goal of PROGRESS is to improve access to family planning among underserved populations through research and research utilization. To achieve this goal, PROGRESS developed a workplan consisting of four legacy areas. The legacy areas comprise the key organizing structure for identifying and implementing activities, monitoring performance, and assessing achievement of desired outcomes. The legacy areas: 1. Maximizing human resources by task-shifting and addressing medical barriers to family planning services 2. Expanding service delivery options within and beyond the health sector 3. Expanding the family planning method mix for home, community, and lower-level provider use 4. Increasing in-country capacity for research and research utilization.

column8: GFSI: Agri-business and Market Development Project (AMDe) . The AMDe project aims to enhance access to finance, stimulate innovation and private sector investment, and increase the competitiveness of select value chains in these AGP targeted woredas. Focus commodity value chains under AMDe include maize, wheat, coffee, sesame, honey, and chickpea, which were prioritized by the GoE and AGP donors mainly for their market potential.

column7: LIVESTOCK MARKETING DEVELOPMENT - AGRICULTURAL SECTOR CAPACITY
column8: GFSI: The project will work closely with the dairy farm cooperatives and dairy processor and producers to address dairy constraints along the value chain. The new project will focus on milk-shed development, artificial insemination services, stimulating business development and market linkages, and provide technical assistance. The project will also provide training on management, marketing and dairy technology.

column6: Graduation with Resilience to Achieve Sustainable Development (GRAD) - Agricultural Sector Capacity
column7: GRADUATION WITH RESILIENCE TO ACHIEVE SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (GRAD) - AGRICULTURAL SECTOR CAPACITY
column8: GFSI: Graduation with Resilience to Achieve Sustainable Development (GRAD) builds on lessons learned from several predecessor USAID projects and activities, including PSNP Plus. An emphasis will be placed on market linkages, access to microfinance, and diversification of household income sources. Additionally, GRAD will also focus on building the resilience of communities through supporting climate change adaptation activities, which will address the high amount of vulnerability in chronically food insecure areas.

column6: Health Finance and Governance (HFG) Project - HIV/AIDS
column7: HEALTH FINANCE AND GOVERNANCE (HFG) PROJECT - HIV/AIDS
column8: USAIDs Global Health Bureau launched the Health Finance and Governance (HFG) Project to support countries in their quest for stronger health systems that deliver the life-saving services their citizens need, when and where they can access them, and at affordable prices. HFG is a five-year (20122017), $209 million global project designed to improve health finance and health governance systems in partner countries, leading to expanded access to health care and improved health outcomes. HFG also works with country partners to improve the management of health systems and generate much-needed evidence on the most effective, efficient ways to improve health systems.
Reproductive Health and Population Planning

column6: Health Policy Project (HPP) - Maternal and Child Health
column7: HEALTH POLICY PROJECT (HPP) - MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH
column8: The Health Policy Project (HPP) works to strengthen developing country national and subnational policy, advocacy, governance, and finance for strategic, equitable, and sustainable health programming. HPP helps countries bring about real change in the health of people and communities. We work with in-country partners to sustain commitment to and ownership of policy responses that support improvements in family planning and reproductive health (FP/RH), HIV, and maternal health.

This is the principal USAID technical service resource in health governance with a focus on fragile states. Health Systems 20/20 focuses on four goals: Finance, Governance, Operations, and Sustainable Capacity:

Reduce the number of deaths caused by TB by increasing detection of cases of TB and by successfully treating detected cases, as well as addressing issues of multi-drug resistant TB, TB and HIV, and investing in new tools for TB.

column6: Systems for Improved Access to Pharmaceuticals and Services (SIAPS) - Tuberculosis
column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - TUBERCULOSIS
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

Promote peaceful agreement on democratic reform, rules, and frameworks. Promote peaceful, broad-based participation in determining, defining, and negotiating changes to governing structures. Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs). Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

column6: Private Sector Productivity - Private Sector Capacity
column7: PRIVATE SECTOR PRODUCTIVITY - PRIVATE SECTOR CAPACITY
column8: Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

Improve early childhood education, primary education, and secondary education, delivered in formal or non-formal settings. It includes literacy, numeracy, and other basic skills programs for youth and adults.

column6: Peace and Reconciliation Processes - Peace and Reconciliation Processes
column7: PEACE AND RECONCILIATION PROCESSES - PEACE AND RECONCILIATION PROCESSES
column8: Support and strengthen the negotiation process and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

column6: Health Finance and Governance (HFG) Project - Tuberculosis
column7: HEALTH FINANCE AND GOVERNANCE (HFG) PROJECT - TUBERCULOSIS
column8: USAIDs Global Health Bureau launched the Health Finance and Governance (HFG) Project to support countries in their quest for stronger health systems that deliver the life-saving services their citizens need, when and where they can access them, and at affordable prices. HFG is a five-year (20122017), $209 million global project designed to improve health finance and health governance systems in partner countries, leading to expanded access to health care and improved health outcomes. HFG also works with country partners to improve the management of health systems and generate much-needed evidence on the most effective, efficient ways to improve health systems.

column7: GRADUATION WITH RESILIENCE TO ACHIEVE SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (GRAD) - CLEAN PRODUCTIVE ENVIRONMENT
column8: Graduation with Resilience to Achieve Sustainable Development (GRAD) builds on lessons learned from several predecessor USAID projects and activities, including PSNP Plus. An emphasis will be placed on market linkages, access to microfinance, and diversification of household income sources. Additionally, GRAD will also focus on building the resilience of communities through supporting climate change adaptation activities, which will address the high amount of vulnerability in chronically food insecure areas.

column6: Systems for Improved Access to Pharmaceuticals and Services (SIAPS) - Malaria
column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - MALARIA
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

column6: Scaling up the Safe Schools Program Through Peace Corps - Public Sector Executive Function
column7: SCALING UP THE SAFE SCHOOLS PROGRAM THROUGH PEACE CORPS - PUBLIC SECTOR EXECUTIVE FUNCTION

column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

column6: Conflict Mitigation and Reconciliation Programs and Activities - Peace and Reconciliation Processes
column7: CONFLICT MITIGATION AND RECONCILIATION PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES - PEACE AND RECONCILIATION PROCESSES
column8: Conflict Mitigation and Reconciliation Programs and Activities - Support and strengthen the negotiation process and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

column6: Systems for Improved Access to Pharmaceuticals and Services (SIAPS) - Malaria
column7: SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED ACCESS TO PHARMACEUTICALS AND SERVICES (SIAPS) - MALARIA
column8: SIAPS focuses on enhancing pharmaceutical services through patientcentered solutions while continuing to support essential supply chain functions and medical products supply security. The SIAPS goal is to support the achievement of improved and sustained health outcomes by applying a systems strengthening approach consistent with the Global Health Initiative (GHI) principles. The SIAPS result areas address the intersections of five health systems components as they pertain to pharmaceutical services (governance, human resources, information, financing, and service delivery) in the design of potential interventions to ensure that they respond to health element and cross cutting concerns in support of health system strengthening.

column6: World Health Organization Consolidated Grant - Malaria
column7: WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION CONSOLIDATED GRANT - MALARIA
column8: This grant provides support for collaborative activities with USAID and the World Health Organization (WHO) in infectious diseases, maternal and child health, family planning, safe motherhood, reproductive health, environmental health and HIV/AIDS. Specifically, support is provided to WHOs relevant technical and program divisions for technical input and assistance in the development, implementation and/or evaluation of health programs and studies including: 1) Global strategy development; 2) Technical analyses; 3) Demonstration activities and feasibility studies; 4) Capacity building; 5) Policy reform; 6) Project evaluation and assessments; 7) Monitoring and evaluation; 8) Education/information strategies; 9) Maternal and neonatal health; 10) Family Planning and Reproductive Health; 11) Implementing Best Practices in Family Planning; and 11) Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC).

The McGovern-Dole program provides for the donation of agricultural commodities and the provision of financial and technical assistance to improve the education, food security and health of school-age children, especially girls, in developing countries.
Wadata Mata Capacity Building Project

Agricultural Services (the Agriculture Activity ): The Agriculture Activity will focus on the basics of irrigated farming and will support a range of interventions that target capacity building, support, and techniques for rice, shallots, livestock and crop integration, and women`s vegetable garden production. During the first two years of the Alatona Irrigation Project, while the road and core irrigation infrastructure are designed and constructed (the pre-settlement phase), efforts will focus on building an institutional environment and testing agricultural, marketing, and water management practices focused on achieving farm profitability. This Project Activity will support a range of agricultural, institutional and related services to strengthen capacity and improve agricultural practice through applied agricultural research, extension and farmer training, support to farmer organizations, and support to water users associations ( WUAs ).

column8: Somali Youth Leaders Initiative - Basic Education - Continue basic subject area learning and skills, including critical analysis, problem solving, and complex communication, beyond lower secondary level. The instruction is highly organized along subject lines, as are textbooks, and teachers need a higher level of subject-specific qualifications. In most countries, this level is the final stage of basic education. Upper Secondary Education is sometimes referred to as high school, senior high school, or senior secondary school.

Prevenir, curar y evitar la propagación de enfermedades infecto-contagiosas en Touba (Diourbel), mediante el fortalecimiento de las capacidades nacionales y locales y la ejecución de actividades de prevención y control adecuadas. Se facilitará el acceso de la población más desfavorecida a la atención primaria de salud y su participación en la gestión del centro construido y equipado.

column6: Improvement of food security through access to production factors, organizational support, training and support to marketing
column7: IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD SECURITY THROUGH ACCESS TO PRODUCTION FACTORS, ORGANIZATIONAL SUPPORT, TRAINING AND SUPPORT TO MARKETING
column8: El objetivo es mejorar la seguridad alimentaria en localidades de la región de Saint Louis y contribuir a la reducción del éxodo rural y la inmigración ilegal. Se intervendrá en cuatro áreas: 1. Acceso a medios de producción para un desarrollo sostenible. 2. Fortalecimiento de las organizaciones de la sociedad civil y refuerzo del enfoque de derechos y género. 3. Refuerzo de las capacidades productivas y de gestión ambiental mediante la introducción de técnicas de manejo sostenible de los cultivos y la introducción de tecnologías de ahorro energético y de consumo de leña. 4. Mejora del acceso a los mercados locales y nacionales de productos agrícolas mediante una estrategia de comercialización para el arroz, la banana y otros cultivos.

column6: Support to the water and sanitation service in rural areas, as well as promotion of low cost technologies.

Así como los territorios liberados por el frente polisario, a través de la observación in situ y el desplazamiento de juristas a los mencionados territorios.

Lucha contra la violación de los derechos humanos de los saharauis tanto en los territorios ocupados por marruecos como los refugiados en argelia y mauritania. column6: Integrated project of fight against malnutrition in urban context.
column7: INTEGRATED PROJECT OF FIGHT AGAINST MALNUTRITION IN URBAN CONTEXT.
column8: El objetivo de este programa es tener un impacto significativo sobre el desarrollo del niño a través de un enfoque preventivo y curativo de la desnutrición aguda en el Distrito de Bamako en Malí. Este objetivo se alcanzará mediante el fortalecimiento de las capacidades de las comunidades y de las instituciones locales y nacionales. La acción se basa en (1) - La identificación precoz y la referenciación al centro de salud de los niños desnutridos por medio de una movilización eficaz de las comunidades y de la búsqueda activa de casos. (2) El tratamiento ambulatorio descentralizado de los niños con desnutrición aguda moderada y severa sin complicación médica importante en los CSCom . (3) El tratamiento de formas severas con complicaciones en la unidad de pediatría del CSRef . (4) La toma en consideración de la problemática VIH/SIDA como causa subyacente de la desnutrición (5) Una movilización social en torno a la problemática relacionada con la desnutrición a través de las actividades de IEC /CCC . (5) la advocacy (defensa) ante los tomadores de decisiones políticos, financieros y operativos.

column6: Strengthening of local capacities in the sanitary district for improving access of population and quality of prevention services.
column7: STRENGTHENING OF LOCAL CAPACITIES IN THE SANITARY DISTRICT FOR IMPROVING ACCESS OF POPULATION AND QUALITY OF PREVENTION SERVICES.
column8: La intervención tiene un enfoque comunitario, centrado en la promoción y prevención de la salud, que se adecúa perfectamente a las prioridades sectoriales y geográficas de la FOCAD a través de la puesta en marcha de las estrategias internacionales como el PCIME (Atención integral a las enfermedades de la infancia) y maternidad sin riesgo (Salud reproductiva y planificación familiar), propugnadas por la OMS y UNICEF y adoptadas por el Ministerio de Salud en Senegal. Basándose en las necesidades y prioridades identificadas en coordinación con los socios locales y beneficiarios/as, el proyecto pretende mejorar el acceso de calidad a los servicios sanitarios por parte de la población civil, enfocando su actuación a 2 niveles y uno de forma transversal: Mejorando, a través de la prevención y el tratamiento, la situación nutricional de menores de 36 meses. Mejorando, a través de la prevención y el tratamiento, la salud materno infantil (SMI). Transversal: Fortalecimiento de las capacidades locales a nivel comunitario y personal del Ministerio de Salud, empoderando el rol de la mujer, con el objetivo de brindar un acceso con calidad de los servicios sanitarios. La intervención propuesta tiene en cuenta el enfoque de género, el fortalecimiento de las capacidades locales, respeto y sostenibilidad ecológica, y el enfoque de derechos están presentes en el proyecto transversalmente a través del cumplimiento de actividades e indicadores puntuales.

column7: ELECTRIFICATION OF RURAL AREAS THROUGH SOLAR ENERGY
column8: ELECTRIFICACION RURAL MEDIANTE ENERGIA SOLAR

column6: Promotion of food security and development in Ross Bethio commune, through supporting women's associations of production and transformation of rice.
column7: PROMOTION OF FOOD SECURITY AND DEVELOPMENT IN ROSS BETHIO COMMUNE, THROUGH SUPPORTING WOMEN'S ASSOCIATIONS OF PRODUCTION AND TRANSFORMATION OF RICE.
column8: El proyecto pretende mejorar las condiciones de vida y la seguridad alimentaria de hogares vulnerables en la Comuna de Ross Béthio (San Louis de Senegal). Para ello, se promoverá la mejora de las capacidades técnicas y organizativas de 2 uniones de mujeres productoras de arroz, mediante: el fomento de sistemas de producción sostenibles, con la dotación de semillas certificadas de arroz, equipamiento agrícola de calidad e instalación de un centro de conservación y tratamiento de arroz; la formación y asesoramiento en técnicas de producción, conservación y envasado de arroz; la promoción del asociacionismo y el liderazgo de las mujeres productoras mediante la creación de una federación; la mejora de la comercialización con la dotación 4 unidades de descascarillado de arroz y formación en técnicas modernas de transformación, control de calidad y comercialización.

column6: Contribute to the improvement of the productive capacities of the returnees of Agnack Small and promote access to nutritious food, is
column7: CONTRIBUTE TO THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE PRODUCTIVE CAPACITIES OF THE RETURNEES OF AGNACK SMALL AND PROMOTE ACCESS TO NUTRITIOUS FOOD, IS
column8: Contribuir a la mejora de las capacidades productivas de la población retornada de Agnack Pequeño y favorecer el acceso a alimentos nutritivos, con especial incidencia en las mujeres :: La propuesta pretende contribuir a la mejora de las capacidades productivas de la población de Agnack Petit. Esto se hace a través del apoyo de las mujeres que trabajan en la huerta de la localidad. Se quiere mejorar el acceso del agua a la huerta a través de la construcción de una pozo, un contrapozo, instalación de una motobomba y una formación para el buen uso y mantenimiento de estos elementos.

column8: Contribuir a la mejora de la situación socio sanitaria de la población afectada por una determinada crisis humanitaria de inicio rápido o emergencia y compleja o de larga duración. Las áreas de intervención son prácticamente mundial en el caso de las emergencias, siempre que se disponga de un operativo internacional

column6: Support to the women community of Djinfangor agricultural activities
column7: SUPPORT TO THE WOMEN COMMUNITY OF DJINFANGOR AGRICULTURAL ACTIVITIES
column8: Apoyo a las actividades agrícolas comunitarias de las mujeres de Djinfangor: Construcción de un depósito elevado de agua, e instalación de una motobomba para distribución de agua de regadío para las huertas. Además, irá acompañado de una formación de dos días para 25 mujeres en uso y mantenimiento de la motobomba.La construcción de este sistema de regadío permitirá a las mujeres una mayor dedicación al rendimiento de la huerta.

column6: Enhancing sanitary capacities and infrastructure in DRASS for comprehensive health attention in Tennuemed
column7: ENHANCING SANITARY CAPACITIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE IN DRASS FOR COMPREHENSIVE HEALTH ATTENTION IN TENNUEMED
column8: El objetivo de APS en la Región del Adrar es el de generar centros específicamente diseñados para las funciones de la salud pública, con bajo coste de mantenimiento, autosuficientes y de agradable imagen para pacientes. _x000D_ El presente proyecto contempla construir y equipar un puesto de salud pública que asista a las poblaciones de Tennuemed y Aín Safra (estimada en más de 6000 personas) fortaleciendo las capacidades institucionales sanitarias, la dotación de servicios y la capacitación práctica del personal sanitario _x000D_ Las líneas fundamentales de esta intervención son:_x000D_ - la construcción y equipamiento del edificio del puesto de salud de Tennuemed con una clara apuesta por la autonomía energética, las reducción del impacto medioambiental y la apertura a la comunidad; _x000D_ - la cobertura de las necesidades de atención primaria de la población de Tennuemed con especial atención a la atención en salud maternal y salud sexual y reproductiva de las mujeres; _x000D_ - la formación a las parteras locales locales a través de la capacitación práctica recibida por parte de la matrona y las actividades de formación llevadas a cabo por las personas voluntarias,_x000D_ - la capacitación al personal sanitario y de gestión y la intervención con la población femenina en la adquisición de pautas de autocuidado sanitario y nutrición saludable;_x000D_ - el impulso a la transversalización de género en la actuación del centro a través de la realización de un estudio sobre las necesidades prácticas y estratégicas de hombres y mujeres en el ámbito de la salud y la sensibilización al personal del centro sobre género y salud y derechos reproductivos de las mujeres_x000D_ El proyecto se inserta en las políticas y servicios públicos del país, de modo que contribuirá a reforzar la propia capacidad del sistema público sanitario

column6: Improvement of socio-economic and environmental situation en rural communities of Diokoul
column7: IMPROVEMENT OF SOCIO-ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL SITUATION EN RURAL COMMUNITIES OF DIOKOUL
column8: Pretende apoyar un proceso coordinado de desarrollo local en cinco colectivades locales de Senagal, en el departamento de Kebémer, región de Louga, Norte del país, para la articulación, programación y conducción de una estrategia endógena de desarrollo económico local, entendido como desarollo, que desde la óptica económica abarca diversas dimensiones, como la social, ambiental, política y cultural

column6: Enhancing sanitary capacities and infrastructure in DRASS for comprehensive health attention in Ain Tayaa (Adrar)
column7: ENHANCING SANITARY CAPACITIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE IN DRASS FOR COMPREHENSIVE HEALTH ATTENTION IN AIN TAYAA (ADRAR)
column8: Las líneas fundamentales de esta intervención son: la construcción y equipamiento del puesto de salud pública de Ain Tayaa, con autonomía energética, la cobertura de las necesidades de atención primaria, con especial atención a la salud maternal y salud s

column6: Reintegrating internal refugees: fight against poverty and exploitation
column7: REINTEGRATING INTERNAL REFUGEES: FIGHT AGAINST POVERTY AND EXPLOITATION
column8: El proyecto tiene por objeto garantizar la protección integral y la seguridad efectiva de los/as desplazados/as internos/as a sus comunidades de origen en las provincias de Kivu Norte, Kivu Sur y Oriental. El objetivo es crear las condiciones favorables para la prevención de la violencia para ese modo evitar de cara al futuro la explotación en el proceso de reintegración de las perosnas beneficiarias. Este proyecto especificamente pretende contribuir a la reintegración de las mujeres desplazadas retornadas a las provincias de Kivu Norte, Kivu Sur y Oriental.
Programa para Fomentar el Desarrollo Sostenible en los ámbitos del comercio y el transporte marítimo en África Occidental

column6: Fight against desertification in Northern Chad: pilot experience for global strategy on cooperation for development.
column7: FIGHT AGAINST DESERTIFICATION IN NORTHERN CHAD: PILOT EXPERIENCE FOR GLOBAL STRATEGY ON COOPERATION FOR DEVELOPMENT.
column8: l presente convenio tiene como objetivo promover en el África Subsahariana la lucha contra la desertificación, con un enfoque de promoción de derechos humanos y equidad de género, para asegurar un desarrollo humano sostenible en la región, partiendo de la experiencia piloto en la comunidad de Gouro, departamento de Ennedi (Norte del Chad). Se pretende analizar las amenazas ambientales a la producción agropecuaria local y los riesgos para la seguridad alimentaria e impulsar un proceso participativo para la elaboración de un plan estratégico de desarrollo de la comunidad que pueda ser implementado, con el apoyo de la cooperación vasca, en otros contextos africanos afectados por las mismas problemáticas.

column6: Preventing sexual violence, enhancement of medical and psychological attention for victims of sexual violence, and reinforcement of health system in N
column7: PREVENTING SEXUAL VIOLENCE, ENHANCEMENT OF MEDICAL AND PSYCHOLOGICAL ATTENTION FOR VICTIMS OF SEXUAL VIOLENCE, AND REINFORCEMENT OF HEALTH SYSTEM IN N
column8: El objetivo del proyecto es contribuir a prevenir la violencia sexual y la transmisión del VIH, promoviendo la atención integral en siete Zonas de Salud de la provincia de Nord Kivu. Para ello se promoverá: (i) la mejora de las capacidades de atención en salud de la red ministerial; (ii) la garantía de una atención específica y de calidad a víctimas de violencia sexual y personas con VIH; (iii) el apoyo a la reinserción socio-económica de las víctimas de violencia sexual; y (iv) la sensibilización comunitaria para la promoción de la salud y la articulación de las medidas necesarias para la prevención e identificación temprana de nuevos casos de violencia contra la mujer.

column6: Alleviating morbi-mortality in children and adults, associated to potable water access
column7: ALLEVIATING MORBI-MORTALITY IN CHILDREN AND ADULTS, ASSOCIATED TO POTABLE WATER ACCESS
column8: La falta de agua potable tiene un impacto negativo directo para la salud y el consecuente Desarollo de los Pueblos de la Comune de Djedougou, provocado por la alta incidencia de enfermedades que padece la población asociadas a la mala calidad del agua. Se pretende dar respuesta a las necesidades detectadas por la población local y expresadas en el diagnóstico participativo realizado de manera que pueda favorecer el acceso al agua potable de la población de 7 comunidades rurales de la comune de Djedougou, distrito de Koulikoro

Chad: Actuación de post-emergencia realizada tras las catastróficas lluvias acaecidas en la región de Tandjilé. Se ha realizado distribución de alimentos, de semillas para las próximas cosechas, de materiales de construcción para la rehabilitación de las casas; y se ha controlado la calidad de las aguas para mejorar las condiciones sociosanitarias y evitar la propagación de enfermedades

column7: IMPLEMENTING A SYSTEM FOR THE PROTECTION OF VULNERABLE INFANTS
column8: Pretende contribuir de manera sostenible a la mejora de la situación material y psicosocial de niñas y niños huérfanos o vulnerables. La intervención cuenta con tres ejes principales: 1- Implementación de un sistema de protección coordinado por parte de los Centros de Desarrollo Familiar con la participación de estructuras comunitarias. 2- Atención a necesidades básicas y psicosociales de las niñas/os. 3- Sesibilización para favorecer la implementación de un sistema de protección.

column6: 10-CO1-010/MANOS UNIDAS/Etiopía/4,3m€/ Food security and access to water in rural communities
column7: 10-CO1-010/MANOS UNIDAS/ETIOPÍA/4,3M€/ FOOD SECURITY AND ACCESS TO WATER IN RURAL COMMUNITIES
column8: 10-CO1-010/MANOS UNIDAS/Etiopía/4,3m?/ Seguridad alimentaria y acceso al agua en comunidades rurales La intervención tiene como objetivo general contribuir a la mejora de la situación de seguridad alimentaria en 19 tabias rurales de las Microcu encas de Bizet-Damo y Wolwalo-Sewne. Comprende dos grandes líneas de ac ción.1. La ampliación de la cobertura de necesidades básicas de agua2. La mejora de la situación económica de las familias, potenciando la pro ductividad agrícola y/o ganadera y la creación de nuevas actividades eco nómicas altenativas para familias que no poseen tierras de cultivo. Par a ello, se prevé la creación y mantenimiento de sistemas de agua, la amp liación de las vías de acceso, la recuperacion biológica del suelo, la c reación y fortalecimiento de organizaciones de agricultores y ganaderos en el buen uso y gestión del agua así como la capacitación en gestión de microempresas, negocios alternativos a la agricultura, cooperativas gan aderas y agrícolas., Transversalvente incide en la sostenibilidad medi oambiental; e incluye la perspectiva de género, a través de promoción de iniciativas que contrarresten las desigualdades que sufren las mujeres en las sociedades rurales.
LINEA DE CREDITO
